captions.text: - Your high school principal here,

poppin' up in your dream
for no apparent reason.

Since I often appear in
many of these throughout

your life, let me give
you some tips on how
to dream more vividly, and even how to
control your dreams.
Keep a dream journal.
Since dreams quickly fade after waking up,

keep a journal by your
bed and write everything
you remember in the present tense.

If you add in any major
issues in your life,

it will eventually help
you see the connection
between your dreams, and your daily life.
Make a dream pillow.

By placing herbs like
lavender, and chamomile

in a small pillow, some
lucid dreamers claim

it will induce lucid
and more vivid dreams.

At the very lest, all
your friends will want
to smell your luxurious face.
Reality checks.
When you're awake, simply say to yourself,
"I can see!
"I can feel!
"I am aware!
"I am!"

This will in turn, make
you hyper aware of when
you are dreaming.
Reality checks are said to be helpful

because they will teach
your body to be aware

of when you are awake and
when you are dreaming.

Lucid dreamers recommend
performing at least
twelve of these reality checks a day.
Meditating.

Lucid dreamers recommend
meditating at least
ten minutes a day.

Meditation is said to
have many positive effects

on the mind and body,
and lucid dream experts
recommend meditating in order to be able
to have vivid, lucid dreams.
Eat cheese, or dairy products.
According to some food scientists,

cheese and dairy products
produce chemicals

that are said to transmit
signals to your brain.

A British study claims
that the sharper the
cheese, the more intense the dream is.

Hopefully, these tips
will lead to more dreams

about riding dragons and
flying through space,
and less about running through your middle
school naked.
So yeah, you're welcome.

comments.author: NerdyCookie

comments.text:
These tips are all bullshit. Lucid dreams, out of body experiences, so 
called astral projections and dreams you can consciously control are all 
different facets of the same thing. Search for The Phase on youtube for 
more on this. We dream when we're having REM sleep, and, on rare 
occuasions, all of our brainwaves are attenuated (small signals) except for 
our gramma brian waves (consciousness waves at 40 Hz), we have spontanious 
experiences of lucid dreams, or out of body experiences, etc. *BUT* you can 
learn techniques to induce this state. Again, watch the The Phase video 
(sorry it's weird because the author is russian and everything's translated 
into english), and download the free book from the link in the discription. 
﻿
